Because at every single recall, we

I can't believe it's been that long.
And love my job.
And what I'd like to be remembered for is two things.
One, that Alzheimer's disease is a spectrum disorder,

So it's very different, for example, from kidney disease,

And the same thing with mild cognitive impairment

to each person's brain.
And the second thing I'd like to be remembered for is

Women going through menopause have cognitive loss,

and when it's not recognized and treated as such,
and unfortunately, in neurology, we don't actually get a menopausal

That systematization, I'm very proud of.

And thank you for being here.

And it reminds me that at the healing temple of the

Thank you Beverly and the Helix Center for hosting this discussion.
I think this discussion sort of came out of the talk that we had at that dinner where
we were talking about if history is the collective memory of a nation, then what happens when
it happens if you're consistently missing from that story or you're constantly vilified
in it.
So, you know, what happens to your present and how does it affect your future?
So I used to be at NPR which deals with the history of the moment, but I think my husband
writes history and looks at history at a longer range.
And I think that perspective is important and because I'm married to him, I've been given
the opportunity to look at a slice of history through a perspective and a lens that is often
not shared and that's the Japanese American or Asian American history.
And if you look at that, America can look very, very different and so can freedom, the
idea of freedoms.
So my project that I would like to be remembered for is it's called Freedom from Fear Yellable
Project.
I'm a conceptual artist, although I use ceramics.
It's really about history and about identity, time, memory.
So I took 120 yellow tea bowls that I hand pinched and I took them to all 10 US concentration
camps that was in the United States in the 1940s and I photographed them.
And because of that, they've sort of been invited to different places.
I have to say not many people like this story and there's been a pushback on it, but I really
thank this panel for giving me a platform.
Thank you.
So Richard, you agreed to start the discussion itself?
Yes, I drew the short straw because everybody else was keeping sensibly quiet.
I think I just begin as, you know, I'm not a psychiatrist, psychoanalyptal, any of those
disciplines with having read recently Paul Licker's book, Memory, History, Forgetting.
And in that book, he has 79 in his index and contents pages together, 79 different categories
under memory.
So where on earth does one start?
And I thought that to start the ball rolling, I would refer to Sigmund Freud who saw memory
as constantly transforming, reorganizing, revising.
And that, even in our introductory comments that people have made, was acknowledged.
But I want to start by asking the other members of the panel, the other point that Freud makes.
And he says that memory is essentially creative.
What do people think he meant by that?
And how does that tie in with your own studies?
I think I can start.
Yes, so to get to these questions, let's remind ourselves and who is listening to us
that memories come in different flavors.
As you mentioned, they give 79 categories of memories.
And of course, there are different ways to categorize them.
One or two major ways that in neuroscience we use to categorize memories is according
to their duration.
Long-term memories, shorter memories.
Shorter memories, they last for a very short time.
Long-term memories, they last for a long time.
That's very easy to remember.
And why are they different?
They are different because the mechanisms that the brain used to make and express these
memories are different.
And another way to categorize them is according to what they do.
There are different memory systems and different types of memories.
We have declarative explicit memories, or we have, in contrast to this, implicit type
of memories.
For example, the explicit declarative memories are the memories we talk about.
So if we are here today and we talk about what we have learned, those are declarative
memories.
And in the same system, also, memories of general knowledge, if I say city, you all
know what I mean by that concept.
So those are part of one memory system which is processed by the media temporal lobe that
has been demonstrated by many, many studies in humans as well as in non-human animals.
If part of this memory system is impaired or their activity is blocked, those memories
do not fall.
Those long-term memories do not fall.
As opposed to other major system of memory, the implicit type of memories, the memories
of how to do things, they are not spoken, they are performed.
For example, if we go skiing, we have to learn how to ski and then we remember.
Those are very strong memories.
Memories of how to drive a car, ride a bike, tie your shoes.
Everything we do that we learn and memorize which become sort of automatic, those are
part of the implicit memory systems.
But it's not talking about muscle memory.
Muscle memory is performance.
So the performance includes the muscle memories.
And those are part of the implicit memory system because we perform those memories.
We execute them in an implicit way.
We don't think about.
After we have learned, we don't think about how to turn the wheel when we drive a car.
We just do it automatically.
And in the same implicit memory system we have also emotional memories.
Memories that are expressed without a conscious awareness.
So the other distinction is conscious awareness versus not.
Implicit types of memories are not conscious in their expression.
And explicit type are.
So there are many different types of memory.
I don't want to go on and on because it's a long story.
So is it a creative process like Freud suggested?
So first of all, I have to say the Freud was brilliant in predicting, let's say, in his
writing so many aspects and processes that we then in neuroscience discovered in the memory
domain.
Is it a creative process?
I think I, yes, I do agree.
And why?
Because when we form memories and they are stored, if we need to retrieve them, because
there are recollections, something that reminds us of whatever happened in our history, in
that precise moment, we are living a different experience at a different time.
So now the new experience in the present is going to be associated somewhat to whatever
is recalled and is going to be restored in another context.
So that is already a processing of the memories, which happens, as you can imagine, every moment,
every day.
But also we re-elaborate memories.
So if we think about something and we recall experiences and we start thinking about something
as because of an emotional, for example, an emotional experience that is so important
to us, we start creating associations, new associations, which will become new memories.
And so the creative process is about who we are made of the multitude of experiences through
learning, memorization, recollections, and re-elaboration.
I hope that gives some topic for discussion.
I might compliment that by answering Richard's question in a slightly different way.
I mean, I hear when I think of whether memory is a creative process, to which I also ascents,
I think that my interpretation is to say that memories are not necessarily lyrical.
In other words, they're not necessarily representative of the world that's out there because they
are interpreted through this objective self.
And it really puts to the point whether if we could view everyone's memories, other
humans or non-humans, whether we would recognize them.
In other words, whether they are even understandable or kind of interpretable or translatable by
others.
And so to me, that's a very generative way to begin this conversation and thinking, as
Christina said, not only about the re-encoding and the changing of memory that happens with
remembering, but also about the very creativity of memory to begin with, that it is an interpretation
of a moment or a scene or a fact or an experience.
And says something is incorporated with the self, which might be impossibly subjective.
I agree with you, Alexandra and Christina as well.
I think all memory is a fabrication of our brain.
Every single memory we have, reality is really truly a fabrication of our brains.
And it's an individual reality, which is not necessarily parallel to the reality of someone
right next to you because it's always filtered through your experience, through your neural
networks, through your interpretations, and through your editing of what you see.
So not only are you going to have alteration and distortion of memory as you recall, but
you also have a true editing and distilling of memory as you lay it down.
So there's a tremendous amount of editing that goes on in both the laying down of memory,
what you choose to attend to, how you choose to store it, what you choose to link it to,
whether or not it's real.
Again, all reality is a fabrication of our individual brains.
And then how you choose to reproduce it, which is always going to be different from
one person to the next.
Even if you agree on the generalities, the details are going to be different because
each of us choose us to remember something different.
So Freud was absolutely correct in terms of how he formulated memory.
Hello.
Yeah.
I have to say that I think there's a difference between personal memory and collective, you
know, national memory, like history.
And I think one of the battles that we're having in America right now is for the story
and the history of America.
And basically there is a narrative that starts with Columbus and there's George Washington
and, you know, Adams and, you know, Jefferson and then it goes to Lincoln and then FDR and
then we're at today.
And in that story, the history of the original people that were here is missing, for example.
There was a survey about five years ago.
I think they found out that 40% of Americans believe that no Native Americans are alive
today and that they are extinct like dinosaurs.
And you know, if you read our newspapers and our history books, you sort of believe that.
They're actually very much alive.
A lot of them were put on reservations.
They've moved into cities to survive and they're still there.
And the other story that never gets out, it's usually race is a big issue today.
And the reason why race is often only seen in a white and black dichotomy is because
the whole history of non-white laws is never talked about in our history books.
And the not white laws were all determined in our court of law and they came out after
the Civil War.
So it was determined in 1870, which was an update of the original naturalization law
of 1790, which said that only white people can become a citizen, was changed in 1870
to include Africans and persons of African descent.
So after that, there's been law after law after law, which people who were not African,
but who were deemed not white had to go to court because they were excluded from citizenship,
from practicing law, from marrying other people, from, you know, they couldn't even testify
against white people.
Chinese could not testify against white people.
And then all Asian people were banned from the United States in 1924, which was actually
the first year that Native Americans were allowed to naturalize.
So there's this whole history that's missing.
So I mean, is that a creative process?
Maybe it is.
Creative doesn't always mean good, right?
Yeah.
You tend to think creative means good, but it doesn't have to be creative in an evil way.
Right?
It's almost...
Even thoughts?
To me, it's almost like what Cetsco is saying, it's almost a destructive process in that
we can create memories, but we can also...
I mean, one of the big questions that people ask is, can we actually remove memories?
So unpleasant memories, can we remove them for our own benefit?
And unfortunately, maybe what you're describing is a sense of that there's injustice happening.
And so people choose not to talk about it.
And so if we don't reinforce that type of information and it's the same with our own memories, if

time and we forget about them.
And what we tend to, we can often choose what we want to remember.
So there's a lot of work out there where people should say, can we suppress certain

And so the ones that give us the joy, the ones that we think other people will enjoy listening

like to talk about a lot.
And so those are the memories that are strengthened and those are the ones that propagate and

Unfortunately, those are the ones that get destroyed and not talked about as much.
And I think that raises the issue very often of whose memory is it?
Is does one have one's own memory?
Does one have parents' memories, ancestral memories?
Who's memory do we think is what we are recalling and registering and being imprinted by?
Richard?
Richard?
Of course, one can have one's memory impaired, but I think the whole question of what is
forgetting is another issue.
But I'd like also to introduce this idea which comes to me from having read Jonathan
Puhrer's book, Moon Walking with Einstein, when he talks about the power of memory.
And in our introductions, we talked about failures of memory or where the memory faculty is hurt.
But he says, well, not only did the ancient Greeks have a god of memory because they thought
it was so important, but we know whether it's from chess players or lorry drivers playing
air chess or even taxi drivers who you probably know in London have to take a particular test.
They have to learn all the places and all the streets in the city.
And it's been tested or shown that taxi drivers have expanded brains through having trained
their facility in this way.
But when they give up their career as taxi drivers, that expansion shrinks again.
And it raises the question of to what extent can we build up our powers of memory?
If we've got people like taxi drivers or chess players improving their memory or conjurers
indeed, what can we do to make the memory faculty of our brains more powerful and be
able to do more with them?
So Richard, so you actually doesn't take much effort to change your brain at a physical
level.
You can practice violin for two days and change the amount of your brain you can physically
demonstrate more area of your brain devoted to that practice.
One thing I wanted to mention which you brought up and wanted to emphasize is we all tend
to prize memory, including the ancient Greeks, but forgetting is just as important for remembering.
And to be able to forget and to be able to normally forget is important for learning.
I mean, if we didn't forget to crawl and we're willing to, then we wouldn't have learned
to walk.
If we didn't forget our first love, it would be hard to fall in love again.
So forgetting is very, if we forgot, if we didn't forget to babble, it would be harder
to learn to.
So it's important to understand, and there's this whole emphasis in modern society of having
to remember and memory being equated with intelligence and kind of to the detriment of
the importance of forgetting.
So I'd like to be a proponent of that forgetting is very good for us and important for our
brain.
And this wonderful book by Luria, Russian psychologist called the mind of the monist
and he talks about a patient or a man who was studied who forgot how to forget.
And it significantly interfered with his ability to function in a daily, in a productive way
on a daily basis.
I'd like to teach my dogs to remember commands better.
Alexandra, I don't know how to do that and not forget.
You know, that you also remind me of the Borges story, Funez the memorial, right, where he
represents a character who could not forget and actually how crippling it was and disabling
of being able to act.
And there are a lot of questions that have already come up.
But I mean, to the sort of how do we remember better, how does a nonhuman remember better,
that's so interesting because I think it has a lot to do with our directing of their
attention, right, in our inability to realize what a salient to them in order to allow for
the encoding, which is easy for them to do that I think can easily learn commands, learn
to remember commands.
But we're not always as good at creating an environment which allows them to pick up
on the salient cues.
But if I can also just add one other thing to this like interestingly frothy sea of ideas,
it was something that Seth's go and Andy were hitting on about a cultural memory and how
exclusion of people from a cultural history is a kind of power that those who are doing
the excluding have over the excluded.
And I was thinking about how when studying nonhuman animals, there's always a question
of whether they have memory at all, right, and this is partially because we can't ask
animals to do memory tasks and give us verbal responses as are many of our memory tasks,
right.
And so even though nonhuman animals are studied for their memory as analogs to human memory,
still what I will be asked about dogs, you know, do they, can they remember anything,
which is which is ridiculous.
Of course they can.
I mean, all their behavior evinces it, but because we can't see into their brains, we
kind of assume that maybe there's an absence there.
And I'm wondering if the sort of way we disallow nonverbal others from having memory is similar
to the kind of historical exclusion, memorial exclusion of peoples from our history.
I'm just seeing an interesting analog there.
I like to say something here because I was shaking my head because there is so much work
done on memories in nonhuman animals.
And of course they have memories.
We can say that they are not talking to us, but that's just one single way to express
memories.
Memories is how to do things is how to recognize places is how to navigate spaces.
We have tons and tons of evidence in nonhuman animals that they have memories and memories
are like any other thing evolutionarily conserved.
And there is so much studies ongoing to understand the biological basis of memories that have
shown that in different species, there are a number of conserved biological mechanisms.
So certainly they're not declarative memories, but I disagree to even doubt that nonhuman
animals have memories.
And I want to bring to one more point, which I think it was brought up in terms of memories
and the subjectivity, the individual ways of memorizing and remembering and processing
information.
I'm not sure we choose to do that.
I'm not sure it's a choice because a lot of our representations and memories are implicit.
So we're not conscious of it.
So we don't have choice in that sense is the unconscious part of brain that guides our
decisions.
And those are, of course, based on experiences and recollection of memories and experiences
we have over and over or new experiences that we have at some point.
We react in certain ways according to our history.
That's why it's very individualized.
So we are studying now in the lab something that to me is very exciting.
And that is how the memory system establish itself.
How do they form?
How does it mature?
And so we are looking at the biology of episodic memories in rats and mice at the age of infancy.
When we know that those memories are formed but rapidly forgotten.
And this very rapid forgetting is believed to be the reason for infantile amnesia.
The process, I don't know how to call it, the phenomenon by which as adults we do not
recall experiences of the first, let's say, three years of life.
And Freud gave the first explanation of infantile amnesia.
We don't think it now is in agreement with what we see.
But now we are studying the biology of these memories forming the first few days corresponding
to the first few years of life in humans.
And found that there is in fact the very conservative evolutionary concern rapid forgetting.
The animals learn and they forget very rapidly compared to later ages.
And when we look at the biology we found that the biology is very interesting and unique
different than the other ages.
They use mechanism of so-called critical periods.
Those are temporal windows in life in which the brain is particularly responsive to experience.
And with these responses it matures the functions.
So let's say the visual system that has been studied a lot in the critical periods.
We are born, we don't see the way we see in adult.
And through seeing through the function of seeing, so all the stimulus they go in through
the eyes and the brain, those shapes the brain to the point that when it's matured is able
to function like in adulthood.
So we find the same similar mechanisms in our experiments of episodic learning and memories.
So what this tells us is that during this temporal window we better have the best stimuli and
experiences to mature our abilities to learn and remember.
And we tested and found that it is the type of experience that matures the function.
In other words, if they are exposed to one type of experience they mature the ability
to memorize like adults, that type, that domain of experience is but not other types that
are processed by the same system.
Christina, could I ask, can one will oneself to forget?
Can one, can one will oneself to forget?
Decide to forget?
Can one make oneself forget?
Well, I'm sure if you start saying I'm going to change my attention and not pay attention
to whatever you want to exclude, over time that will lead to more forgetting than if
you don't do that.
But that is one single, it's a small part of the memories compared to all the memories
we have.
The memories we have is the expression of the experiences.
And our brain is molded according to the experiences we have.
And during these critical periods what we see is key for the development of the function.
You know, Richard, I just wanted to say something to Richard for a moment.
In Ovid's Metamorphosis, the ability to forget is really described, meant to drink of the
river of Lethe.
And that was a major part of the Orphic, the whole Orphic experience of creative transformation.
And so all of those metamorphoses, all those transformations depended in Ovid on that ability
to forget.
So I think that that's been part of our sort of more reflective experience of memory in
the brain.
That's a good pick up.
There's an actual book by David Rief called In Praise of Forgetting.
Yes.
He makes the point that remembering is a barrier to reconciliation, whether it's between nations,
between couples or whatever, which is why that part of memory is so important.
Yes.
And in the patients, you often get that someone cannot forgive and then they get to an age
where they forget.
And then there's reconciliation.
Actually one of the happiest, you know, one of the keys to happiness I found in older
patients is the ability to forgive, to truly forgive and forget.
And the one other point I wanted to make for Richard's question was that forgetting is
almost an unconscious, incessant, constant process.
As we're listening right now, there are so many things that we're forgetting.
I'm forgetting the way the light falls in the room.
